See Textbook 1.3(27,28) for some various identities related to propositional logic (such as $p \implies q \equiv \neg p \lor q$)

Logical Equivalences ($\equiv$)

$a \equiv b \iff (a \iff b)$ is a tautology (equivalent, if the truth tables of $a,b$ are the same)

$p \implies q \equiv \neg q \implies \neg p \not\equiv q \implies p$

De Morgan's Laws

$\neg (p \land q) \equiv \neg p \lor \neg q$
$\neg (p \lor q) \equiv \neg p \land \neg q$

Others:

Identity Laws
$p \land T \equiv p$
$p \lor F \equiv p$

$p \lor T \equiv T$
$p \land F \equiv F$

$p (\lor,\land) p \equiv p$

$\neg \neg p \equiv p$

Commutative Laws $\checkmark$

Associative Laws $\checkmark$

Distributive Laws $\checkmark$

Absorption Laws
$p \lor (p \land q) \equiv p$
$p \land (p \lor q) \equiv p$

Implication Laws
$p \implies q \equiv \neg p \lor q$
$p \implies q \equiv \neg q \implies \neg p$ (contrapositive)

Example

Show that $p \land q \equiv \neg (\neg p \lor (p \land \neg q))$
$\neg (\neg p \lor (p \land \neg q)) \equiv p \land \neg (p \land \neg q) \equiv p \land (\neg p \lor q) \equiv (p \land \neg p) \lor (p \land q) \equiv F \lor (p \land q) \equiv (p \land q) \square$

Show that $p \land q \implies p$ is a tautology
$p \land q \implies p \equiv \neg (p \land q) \lor p \equiv \neg p \lor \neg q \lor p \equiv T \lor \neg q \equiv T \square$

1.4 Predicate Logic

$P(x): x \gt 3$ is not a proposition, but a predicate that becomes a proposition when a value of $x$ is assigned; that is, it is a propositional function of $x$

$P(1) \equiv F, P(5) \equiv T$

Given $P(x):$ "Planet $x$ has $7$ moons, express
1. There is a planet with $7$ moons
2. All planets have $7$ moons

1a. $\exists x : P(x)$
2a. $\forall x : P(x)$
